item.title: North Korea May Be Linked To WannaCry Ransomware, Researchers Say
item.description: May 16, 2017 - Google security researcher Neel Mehta pointed out similarities between WannaCry and malware used by Lazarus, the group that's been blamed for the Sony Pictures hack of 2014.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 16, 2017 - Google security researcher Neel Mehta pointed out similarities between WannaCry and malware used by Lazarus, the group that's been blamed for the Sony Pictures hack of 2014. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/16/528587064/north-korea-may-be-linked-to-wannacry-ransomware-researchers-say

item.title: From Kill Switch To Bitcoin, 'WannaCry' Showing Signs Of Amateur Flaws
item.description: May 16, 2017 - There's very little law enforcement can do to catch purveyors of ransomware — unless they slip up. The criminals behind the WannaCry attack may have done just that.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 16, 2017 - There's very little law enforcement can do to catch purveyors of ransomware — unless they slip up. The criminals behind the WannaCry attack may have done just that. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/05/16/528570788/from-kill-switch-to-bitcoin-wannacry-showing-signs-of-amateur-flaws

item.title: Cyberattack Culprits Demand Ransom Be Paid In Bitcoins
item.description: May 16, 2017 - Hackers have been targeting users and demanding bitcoins as ransom. Since not all their victims have used bitcoin before, they've been sending their victims bitcoin tutorials.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 16, 2017 - Hackers have been targeting users and demanding bitcoins as ransom. Since not all their victims have used bitcoin before, they've been sending their victims bitcoin tutorials. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/16/528570753/cyberattack-culprits-demand-ransom-be-paid-in-bitcoins

item.title: Microsoft President Urges Nuclear-Like Limits On Cyberweapons
item.description: May 16, 2017 - Microsoft President Brad Smith calls for a "Digital Geneva Convention" under which governments would set limits on the creation of cyberweapons, just like they did for nuclear weapons.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 16, 2017 - Microsoft President Brad Smith calls for a "Digital Geneva Convention" under which governments would set limits on the creation of cyberweapons, just like they did for nuclear weapons. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/05/16/528555400/microsofts-president-reflects-on-cyberattack-helping-pirates-and-the-nsa

item.title: Former White House CIO Outlines How To Safe Guard Against Malware
item.description: May 15, 2017 - NPR's Audie Cornish talks with cybersecurity expert and former White House Chief Information Officer Theresa Payton about consumer protection against malware and what to do if you're hit with ransomware.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 15, 2017 - NPR's Audie Cornish talks with cybersecurity expert and former White House Chief Information Officer Theresa Payton about consumer protection against malware and what to do if you're hit with ransomware. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/15/528502953/former-white-house-cio-outlines-how-to-safe-guard-against-malware

item.title: Hackers Likely Stole NSA Research To Conduct Global Ransomware Attack
item.description: May 15, 2017 - The ransomware attacks hitting European and Asian computers were made in part possible by National Security Agency research into computer exploits. NPR's Audie Cornish talks to researcher Nicholas Weaver about these leaked exploits and how they compromise U.S. intelligence.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 15, 2017 - The ransomware attacks hitting European and Asian computers were made in part possible by National Security Agency research into computer exploits. NPR's Audie Cornish talks to researcher Nicholas Weaver about these leaked exploits and how they compromise U.S. intelligence. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/15/528502904/hackers-likely-stole-nsa-research-to-conduct-global-ransomware-attack

item.title: Ransomware Attacks Begin To Stabilize After Compromising Networks Worldwide
item.description: May 15, 2017 - The volume of ransomware attacks is slowing or stabilizing around the world, according to government officials and security experts. And the amount of ransom paid out by victims is relatively small — just tens of thousands of dollars. But the scope of the attack in more than 100 countries is still massive, its disruptions are widespread, and the weaknesses it exposed in computer systems can only be described as frightening.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 15, 2017 - The volume of ransomware attacks is slowing or stabilizing around the world, according to government officials and security experts. But the scope of the attack in more than 100 countries is still massive, its disruptions are widespread, and the weaknesses it exposed in computer systems can only be described as frightening. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/15/528502897/ransomware-attacks-begin-to-stabilize-after-compromising-networks-worldwide

item.title: WannaCry Ransomware: What We Know Monday
item.description: May 15, 2017 - A Homeland Security official says that so far, "the U.S. is still in a relatively good place." But because of the malware's success, it is being tweaked to foil attempts to stop its spread.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 15, 2017 - A Homeland Security official says that so far, "the U.S. is still in a relatively good place." But because of the malware's success, it is being tweaked to foil attempts to stop its spread. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/15/528451534/wannacry-ransomware-what-we-know-monday

item.title: WannaCry Ransomware: Microsoft Calls Out NSA For 'Stockpiling' Vulnerabilities
item.description: May 15, 2017 - The NSA's losing control of the software behind the WannaCry cyberattack is like "the U.S. military having some of its Tomahawk missiles stolen," Microsoft President Brad Smith says.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 15, 2017 - The NSA's losing control of the software behind the WannaCry cyberattack is like "the U.S. military having some of its Tomahawk missiles stolen," Microsoft President Brad Smith says. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/15/528439968/wannacry-ransomware-microsoft-calls-out-nsa-for-stockpiling-vulnerabilities

item.title: Global Cyberattack Spreads, U.S. Avoids Worst Of It
item.description: May 15, 2017 - Universities, hospitals, railways and other institutions in China are the latest targets. David Greene talks to Michael Chertoff, who served as Homeland Security secretary under President Bush.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 15, 2017 - Universities, hospitals, railways and other institutions in China are the latest targets. David Greene talks to Michael Chertoff, who served as Homeland Security secretary under President Bush. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/15/528432310/global-cyber-attack-spreads-u-s-avoids-worst-of-it

item.title: Repercussions Continue From Global Ransomware Attack
item.description: May 14, 2017 - The latest global cyberattack is believed to be the biggest extortion attack recorded, with more than 200,000 people affected in 150 countries. But ransomware has been around for years.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 14, 2017 - The latest global cyberattack is believed to be the biggest extortion attack recorded, with more than 200,000 people affected in 150 countries. But ransomware has been around for years. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/14/528355526/repercussions-continue-from-global-ransomware-attack

item.title: AP Test-Takers' Tweets May Not Give Away Answers, But They Raise Questions
item.description: May 14, 2017 - Memes about the advanced placement exams turned up on social media recently. Do they break the rules or do they highlight a deeper issue of inequality?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 14, 2017 - Memes about the advanced placement exams turned up on social media recently. Do they break the rules or do they highlight a deeper issue of inequality? http://www.npr.org/2017/05/14/528140036/ap-test-takers-tweets-may-not-give-away-answers-but-they-raise-questions

item.title: Security Researcher And Microsoft Worked To Stop Spread Of Cyberattack
item.description: May 13, 2017 - NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks about the implications of Friday's massive cyberattack with Michael Sulmeyer, director of the Cyber Security Project at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 13, 2017 - NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks about the implications of Friday's massive cyberattack with Michael Sulmeyer, director of the Cyber Security Project at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/13/528287801/security-researcher-and-microsoft-worked-to-stop-spread-of-cyberattack

item.title: Cyber Security Experts Say Malware Used In Friday's Attack Is Especially Malicious
item.description: May 13, 2017 - Cybersecurity professionals from more than 100 countries are working to restore computer systems that were paralyzed by Friday's unprecedented global ransomware attack.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 13, 2017 - Cybersecurity professionals from more than 100 countries are working to restore computer systems that were paralyzed by Friday's unprecedented global ransomware attack. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/13/528287794/cyber-security-experts-say-malware-used-in-fridays-attack-is-especially-maliciou

item.title: Security Expert Weighs In On Worldwide Ransomware Hack
item.description: May 13, 2017 - NPR'S Scott Simon speaks with Matt Tait, of Capital Alpha Security in the United Kingdom, about the ransomware hacks in dozens of countries on Friday.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
